intro: Chamaesyce conferta, commonly known as the clustered sandmat, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a low-growing, mat-forming perennial that thrives in arid and semi-arid environments. The plant features small, fleshy, ovate leaves that are typically covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss. Its flowers are yellow and borne in clusters, adding a delicate touch to its compact form. Chamaesyce conferta is well adapted to harsh conditions, making it a resilient plant in desert ecosystems.
